feed.title: Mental Health Online
feed.subtitle: Change?? awesome description for your new site here. You can edit this line in _config.yml. It will appear in your document head meta (for Google search results) and in your feed.xml site description.

entry.title: Web-based Interventions
entry.content:
Adapting with Technology

Benefits of online interventions

Web-based interventions come in many shapes and sizes: meditation apps, internet-guided therapy, self-help educational serivices, skills-based therapy apps, and more! They can be made for a more general audience, or more niche for specific needs within specific populations.

The primary benefit of these services is that they’re incredibly accessible, being that they’re available immediately and 24/7, and generally cheaper than traditional therapy (even free in some cases). Research shows that some web-based interventions and internet guided therapies can be effective at reducing stress (Heber et al., 2017) and share similar outcomes to face-to-face psychotherapy (Andersson & Titov, 2014)!

Generally, web-based interventions can be used to supplement other mental health services (such as traditional therapy), but can be beneficial even when used in isolation.


Web-based Interventions:

(Note that these lists will not be exhaustive or cover every issue. If you have suggestions or concerns, contact me.)
  • Headspace: Meditation & Sleep
Headspace is a mental health and meditation-focused app. While their primary focus is targeting stress, anxiety, and sleep through evidence-based meditation and mindfulness practices, they also cover other topics.
Available on: Apple Appstore (4.8 stars), Google Play (4.4 stars), and Online Web Browser
Price: $69.99 annually ($5.83/mo) or $12.99 monthly
Free trial options available; 14 days with annual membership, and 7 days with monthly membership.


  • Clarity: CBT Self Help Journal
Clarity is a self-help journal with lessons and guidance on developing therapeutic skills to target common mental health concerns, like Anxiety, Depression, and ADHD. Clarity integrates therapeutic practices from Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), as well as other models like Dialectrical Behavior Therapy (DBT), Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), and more.
Available on: Apple Appstore (4.8 stars), and Google Play (3.8 stars)
Price: Basic app services are FREE! However, there is a paid "pro version" available for $59.99/year ($4.99/mo)
7 day free trial available.


  • Togetherall
Togetherall is a service that provides a "diverse and safe online community" for people to share their feelings and support other community members. It provides resources and peer-to-peer support to address a range of mental health topics.
Available primarily on their website, both on laptop and mobile phones.
Price: FREE, but you must be eligible through your university, insurance, or other institutions.
Find out if you qualify here.
References

Andersson, G., & Titov, N. (2014, February). Advantages and limitations of internet-based interventions for common mental disorders. World psychiatry: official journal of the World Psychiatric Association (WPA). https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3918007/

Heber, E., Ebert, D. D., Lehr, D., Cuijpers, P., Berking, M., Nobis, S., & Riper, H. (2017). The benefit of web- and computer-based interventions for stress: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Medical Internet Research, 19(2). https://doi.org/10.2196/jmir.5774

entry.title: Connecting with Mental Health Professionals
entry.content:
A Great First Step

Benefits of Therapy

Therapy is a treatment that aims to reduce emotional distress and improve some parts of life. In traditional forms of psychotherapy, it involves recurring meetings with a mental health professional, where the patient and therapist work collaboratively to identify and improve the patient’s mental health concerns (Psychology Today, n.d.).


A common misconception is that therapy only helps people with “serious” mental health issues–that’s definitely not the case! There’s a vast amount of things these professionals can provide help with. Here’s a few, just to scratch the surface:

  • Increasing life satisfaction, productivity, etc.
  • Loss, grief, and life transitions
  • Emotional and/or psychological pain
  • Dealing with and overcoming trauma
  • Physical symptoms (e.g., chronic pain, sleep disorders)

If you’d like to see more, check out this link!


Virtual or In-person? What’s the difference?

Another common (and understandable) question is, “Would face-to-face therapy be ‘better’ than virtual therapy?” Virtual therapy involes meeting your therapist online through a video-and-audio service, like Zoom, and has become increasingly more popular, especially since COVID-19. The benefit of virtual therapy is that you can do it in the comfort of your own home, making it more accessible for people without access to transportation, and allowing you to reach therapists otherwise physically unavailable.

However, some individuals express concern that the virtual format may mean therapy is less effective than it would be in person. While it is true that some therapists find it’s somewhat harder to read nonverbal cues virtually, research has found no significant difference in the effectiveness between virtual and in-person therapy (Waite et al., 2022)!


What types of professionals are there, and what do they do?

While looking for the professional that works best for you, you’ll want to consider things like: training and education, what specializations they have, and your financial situation. Many professionals will take insurance, but if you don’t have insurance, some services also provide sliding-scale payment options!


  • Psychiatrists: Medical doctors with psychiatric training.
These professionals have a Doctor of Medicine (MD) or Doctor or Osteopathic Medicine (DO), followed by a residency in psychiatry. On top of being able to diagnose mental health disorders and provide therapy, psychiatrists are able to prescribe and monitor medication for said disorders.
  • Psychologists: Doctors of Psychology
These professionals possess a doctoral degree (PhD or PsyD) in Clinical, Counseling, School or other fields of Psychology. PhDs (Doctor of Philosophy) and PsyDs (Doctor of Psychology) in psychology are both doctoral degrees, but differ in that PhDs are research-focused, whereas PsyDs are mroe oriented towards clinical practice. Psychologists can diagnose mental health disorders and provide therapy, but are not able to prescribe medication.
  • Licensed Professional Counselrs (LPCs): Trained, Masters-level Clinicians
LPCs are mental health professionals with a Masters-level degree in Psychology, and commonly specialize in specific subject areas (e.g., Marriage or Family Therapy, Substance Abuse). These professionals are also trained to identify (and sometimes diagnose) mental health conditions and provide therapy. The actual title of an LPC can vary; you might see counselor, clinician, therapist, etc.
  • Licensed Clinical Social Workers (LCSWs): Masters-level Social Workers w/ therapeutic training
LCSWs are also trained to use therapeutic techniques to address mental health concerns. What differs with social workers is that they typically have a Masters-level education related to social work, meaning they're also trained in case management and advocacy. For social workers, their services and experience depend on their specific certifications.


Finding a Professional:

(Note that these lists will not be exhaustive or cover every issue. If you have suggestions or concerns, contact me.)
  • Psychology Today:
[description]
  • APA’s Psychologist Locator:
[description]
  • Findapsychologist.org:
[description]
  • GoodTherapy.org:
[description]
  • Headway.co:
[description]


References

Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research. (2023, April 14). How to find a good counselor or other mental health provider. Mayo Clinic. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/mental-illness/in-depth/mental-health-providers/art-20045530

Waite, M. R., Diab, S., & Adefisoye, J. (2022). Virtual Behavioral Health Treatment Satisfaction and Outcomes Across Time. Journal of patient-centered research and reviews, 9(3), 158–165. https://doi.org/10.17294/2330-0698.1918

Why Everyone Can Benefit From Therapy. HealthCore Clinic. (2023, January 27). https://healthcoreclinic.org/2023/01/27/why-everyone-can-benefit-from-therapy

Psychology Today. (n.d.). What Is Therapy? https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/therapy

entry.title: Phonelines
entry.content:
Phone lines, Hotlines, and Coldlines

Who you gonna call?

A health professional, probably!

Mental health phone lines are both national and local services provided by liscened counselors and volunteers alike, to provide immediate (or near immediate) mental health support. Phonelines are generally broken up into two categories: Warmlines and Hotlines.

Crisis Hotlines

Hotlines are phonelines that primarily operate to keep you safe and connect you with resources in moments of crisis. Many of these are nation-wide, free, confidential, and available 24/7. For instance, the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline provides support 24/7, nation-wide, for a wide range of mental health struggles (988 Lifeline, n.d.). Additionally, there are also hotlines that specialize in specific content areas. (Find out more below!)

Warmlines

Warmlines, unlike hotlines, are built primarily to allow you to talk with someone for mental health support. However, these absolutely can still be used in moments of crisis (Mental Health America, 2024).

Warmline volunteers are not always licensed counselors (APA, 2020); sometimes, it may be community members or volunteers trained as empathetic listeners, ready to provide peer support. It’s important to note these services are not always 24/7, and are more likely to be local, rather than national. (Find out more below!)

If you would like someone to talk to, but don’t find yourself in crisis, warmlines can be a great place to get some help!


Find Hotlines and Warmlines today:

(Note that these lists will not be exhaustive or cover every issue. If you have suggestions or concerns, contact me.)

Below are several national phonelines to call for various issues, both hotlines and warmlines. However, you may have phonelines local to your state or area. If you’d like to find more about those, you can check out:

  • Warmlines Locator: Click on link provided
Type: Warmline(s)
Information varies by service and state
  • National Alliance on Mental Illness’ Warmline Directory: Click on link provided
Type: Warmline(s)
Information varies by service and state
  • Childhelp National Child Abuse Hotline: (800) 422-4453
Type: Hotline
[Description]
  • Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741
Type: Textline
[Brief description]
  • Disaster Distress Helpline: Call or Text 1-800-985-5990
Type: Hotline and Textline
Languages: Multilingual, over 100 languages
Para español, lama o envía un mensaje de texto 1-800-985-5990 presiona 2.
For Deaf/Hard of Hearing individuals, text or call 1-800-985-5990 using your preferred Relay provider, or find out more by clicking on this link.
[Brief description]
  • Gamblers Anonymous: Find local hotlines at link
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • Nacional de Prevención del Suicidio: (888) 628-9454
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • National Domestic Violence Hotline: (800) 799-7233
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • National Grad Crisis Line: (877) 472-3457
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • National Human Trafficking Hotline: 888-373-7888 or Text HELP to 233733 (BEFREE)
Type: Hotline and Textline
[Brief description]
  • National Sexual Assault Hotline: (800) 656-4673
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • National Suicide and Crisis Lifeline: 988 or Chat online
Type: Hotline and Textline
For Deaf/Hard of Hearing individuals, use your preferred relay service or dial 711 then 988 or Chat online
[Brief description]
  • SAgE’s Farmer Support Hotline: 833-381-SAGE
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration National Helpline: (800) 662-4357
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • The Steve Fund: Text ‘STEVE’ to 741741
Type: Textline
[Brief description]
  • The Trevor Project: 1-866-488-7386 or Text ‘START’ to 678-678 or Message online
Type: Hotline/Warmline and Textline
[Brief description]
  • Trans Lifeline: 877-565-8860
Type: Hotline
[Brief description]
  • Veterans Crisis Line: 988, then press 1 or Text 838255 or Chat online
Type: Hotline and Textline
[Brief description]


References

FORMAT LATER

988 lifeline. 988 Lifeline. (n.d.). https://988lifeline.org/

Need to talk to someone? (Warmlines). Mental Health America. (2024, May 6). https://screening.mhanational.org/content/need-talk-someone-warmlines/?layout=mhats%2Cmhats4a

Warm lines: Providing help before a crisis develops. Psychiatry.org - Warm Lines: Providing Help Before a Crisis Develops. (2020, January 9). https://www.psychiatry.org/news-room/apa-blogs/warm-lines-providing-help-before-a-crisis-develops#:~:text=A%20warm%20line%20is%20a,country%2C%20they%20are%20not%20uniform

entry.title: Web-based Interventions
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
